annotated_bib.problem_stmt: In the US, every ten years states redraw the boundaries of voting districts to conform with the most recent census data. Gerrymandering is the intentional and strategic drawing of voting district boundaries to diminish your political rivals' influence. This can be done by either "packing" a district by relegating a large group of demographically similar people into only a few districts where they make up a majority, or by "cracking" a group by dispersing them between many districts so they never constitute a large enough portion of a constituency to win. This practice deliberately undermines our intended system of representative government. However, with the advent of the computer and the compilation of detailed demographic information into digital databases such as GIS (geographic information system) the use of what are conventionally engineering methods has been suggested as a way to mitigate this. Through the marriage of data optimization with the political process steps can be taken toward depoliticizing a task that should simply be an unbiased and mundane piece of housekeeping to keep our democracy functioning properly.
